category_summary:
Two major stories dominated AI discussions: the **Apple-Google AI partnership** and **Anthropic's Cowork** launch.

- **Jeff Dean** [announced **Gemini** models](/?date=2026-01-13&category=social#item-792b8af41456) will power **Apple Intelligence**, with **Apple** calling Google's AI "the most capable foundation" for their needs
- **Anthropic** [launched **Cowork**](/?date=2026-01-13&category=social#item-2eeb5970b4b4), a general-purpose agent for non-coding tasks like vacation research and email management‚Äîgarnering 6.9K likes and 724K views
- **Simon Willison** [published early impressions](/?date=2026-01-13&category=social#item-826d6be223eb) of Cowork, noting the $100+/month pricing tier

Healthcare AI saw aggressive expansion: **OpenAI** [acquired **Torch**](/?date=2026-01-13&category=social#item-e7e4312e9767) (1.1M views) while **Anthropic** [announced new healthcare connectors](/?date=2026-01-13&category=social#item-218907a9e98c) and Agent Skills.

- **David Ha** (DeepMind) [shared a breakthrough finding](/?date=2026-01-13&category=social#item-af9a3f3891ce): positional embeddings are "training wheels" that hurt long-context generalization
- **Sakana AI** [introduced **DroPE** research](/?date=2026-01-13&category=social#item-cfc338f70630) extending context by dropping positional embeddings post-training
- **Nathan Lambert** [launched the **Relative Adoption Metric**](/?date=2026-01-13&category=social#item-0b3365414835) for analyzing model downloads with size-category bias correction

Ethical concerns about AI companies [scraping public content](/?date=2026-01-13&category=social#item-1d2538229924) "for free, then selling it back as tokens" sparked heated debate.

items.title: Since we launched Claude Code, we saw people using it for all sorts of non-coding work: doing vacati...
items.content:
Since we launched Claude Code, we saw people using it for all sorts of non-coding work: doing vacation research, building slide decks, cleaning up your email, cancelling subscriptions, recovering wedding photos from a hard drive, monitoring plant growth, controlling your oven.

These use cases are diverse and surprising -- the reason  is that the underlying Claude Agent is the best agent, and Opus 4.5 is the best model.

Today, we're so excited to introduce Cowork, our first step towards making Claude Code work for all your non-coding work. The product is early and raw, similar to what Claude Code felt like when it first launched.

Cowork includes a number of novel UX and safety features that we think make the product really special: a built-in VM for isolation, out of the box support for browser automation, support for all your https://t.co/W3YiSA4piu data connectors, asking you for clarification when it's unsure,  We are excited to see how you all use it.

Cowork is available now as a research preview for Claude Max subscribers in the macOS app. Click on ‚ÄúCowork‚Äù in the sidebar: https://t.co/lShyhOcDTV

items.title: One of my favorite findings: Positional embeddings are just training wheels. They help convergence b...
items.content:
One of my favorite findings: Positional embeddings are just training wheels. They help convergence but hurt long-context generalization.

We found that if you simply delete them after pretraining and recalibrate for < 1% of the original budget, you unlock massive context windows.

items.title: Here's more analysis on the Apple and Google deal to make a new kind of Siri, after I had a cup of c...
items.content:
Here's more analysis on the Apple and Google deal to make a new kind of Siri, after I had a cup of coffee.

This is what OpenAI is doing: they're making a variety of new products and going after Apple. Apple didn't want to give OpenAI any more data to help a potential new competitor.

The real problem for this OpenAI effort is that we're about to move to glasses. People don't believe me that we're about to move to glasses, but you should, because I just got back from CES and there was a ton of glasses there.

For OpenAI to really get somewhere, they need to add a camera to an earphone. While I don't see that in this latest report, I won't be shocked to see a camera show up somewhere eventually. 

It is cameras that add understanding of the real world, which can lead to many new features that Apple's current AirPods Pro can't match.

I believe Apple is developing such a product to go with their glasses, which makes a lot of sense. Also, Google's AI models are better at multimodality; this means they can use cameras in a much better way than even OpenAI's models can.

This is why in Silicon Valley robotics companies, a lot of them use Google Gemini: because robots need multimodality.

Apple's glasses, which are expected in 2027, have some significant advantages over the others.

First, they have eye sensors in them, so it knows where the user is looking. It also can tell what the user is touching, holding, or gesturing towards.

This new capability will give Siri a significant parlor trick: it will let Siri answer questions that no other search engine has been able to answer before.

But the real reason I'm still bullish on Apple's glasses isn't technology‚Äîit's content.

Apple has NBA rights and Formula One (among others) and a really great studio system, which has produced one of the biggest hits of the last six months. Pluribus.

Apple also, because of its privacy stance, has a significant lead in consumer trust. Because of its retail stores, it also has a significant lead in the ability to:
1. Show people glasses
2. Get them fit properly
3. Get people trained

On Saturday, I went to the main Apple store in Cupertino and watched one of the classes that they teach every few hours in an Apple store.

The store was packed with people watching the class on a huge screen in the middle of the store. Apple has dramatically changed retail because of its stores, which gives it the most trusted brand in the business and gives it distribution to most of the world's richest people.

While OpenAI has almost a billion users, it is unclear whether those users will switch ecosystems from Apple to OpenAI.

Even if OpenAI's AI and devices can do a few more things, I'm not so sure anybody's going to care when Apple has very capable headphones that match up with their iPhones and has the world's richest people addicted to the Apple ecosystem (me included).

Here is one of the secret Chinese suites at CES, which makes a series of glasses to sell to other brands. This gives you a sense of how fast the glasses world is moving.

AI needs to not just tell you what it's seeing, but it needs to show you things to really make the solution complete.

Also, Apple usually picks a much better design than anyone else. Because it's such a luxury brand, it can charge more than anybody else and be more profitable. 

I don't see anyone else being able to put together the whole solution the way Apple can. Therefore, I am still very bullish on Apple making a dramatic announcement about glasses sometime in the next 24 months.

At CES, though, it's clear that many manufacturers will try. @XREAL_Global just got $100 million of funding to continue its glasses development, and officials of the company told me it will release its Android XR based glasses later this year. 

Short version: AI is coming to wearables in a big way, and Apple will do what it always does: come in late to the market and redefine it when it enters. It still has all the pieces to put together the puzzle, even though it doesn't have its own LLM so had to do a deal with Google for that. 

Yeah, others will be earlier to the market, and will win some buyers because of that, but buyers like me know that and will be happy to put down our other ones to buy Apple because of its advantages. 

With one big caveat: Apple has to deliver an amazing pair of glasses, and maybe a headphone with a camera, to keep the competition from taking its lunch.

Also, behind the scenes there is a big patent battle brewing. Apple has quite a few, but I talked with Ann Greenberg at CES, who started Gracenote. She says she has several patents that will enable a large company to force others to license their technology and that she's already in final stages of selling those patents to a big company. All the big companies have patent portfolios they can use against each other, and particularly smaller, newer, competitors. Microsoft alone has dozens of patents it bought to start off its Hololens efforts, which it gave up on, but Microsoft still has almost 1,000 lawyers who would love to go after other companies for licensing deals. Plus, Google-funded Magic Leap has about 1,000 patents, so it'll be interesting to see if anyone buys the remnants of that company. 

The question is: can anyone disrupt Apple? Especially OpenAI?

items.title: Excited to announce the Relative Adoption Metric a new way of studying model downloads that contextu...
items.content:
Excited to announce the Relative Adoption Metric a new way of studying model downloads that contextualizes it across time and model sizes.

While building The ATOM Project and other tools to measure the open ecosystem at @interconnectsai, we are often frustrated with using downloads as a primary metric. We, and the community, know that small models are downloaded much more, so it makes some adoption metrics favor organizations releasing small models. Over the 1,100+ leading LLMs we track carefully, more than 1.4 billion of ~2 billion total downloads come from models in the 1-9B range.

This small model dominance happens to be partially caused by far more models *being released* at that size. Among the top 10 downloaded models at each size category, the median models from 1-9B parameters are only downloaded about 4X the count of models of 100B+ parameters. Still, this difference combined with the potential of small models to be outliers in downloads‚Äîby being loaded in the continuous integration (CI) tests of ML developers checking their code and other at-scale automated systems‚Äîmakes small models dominate plots.

We created the **Relative Adoption Metric**, reported as a RAM Score, to be able to tell within 30-90 days if a new model is on track to be ecosystem defining. We can already see that some models, such as GPT-OSS, are truly exceptional. In releasing only 2 models, OpenAI is well on the map as a top 5-10 open model lab in adoption metrics‚Äîthis is hard to see when comparing organizations versus each other, when OpenAI's competitors may have many models.

We're also excited to see that some recent larger models from newer AI labs on the scene, such as MiniMax or Moonshot AI, are outperforming the metric, indicating competition in the large MoE space dominated by DeepSeek earlier in the year.

We're excited to support the ecosystem with this new tool!

Some early observations include:
1. GPT-OSS is extremely off the charts. It's on track to be one of the top downloaded models of all time, despite implementation complexity and fairly large sizes (20 & 120B)
2. @MiniMax_AI M2.1 is outperforming most of the recent large Chinese models: @Kimi_Moonshot K2 Thinking is on-track to be in the top 10, DeepSeek v3.2 is underperforming past DeepSeek releases, and @Zai_org GLM 4.7 isn't breaking through as much as I originally thought.
3. @NVIDIAAI's Nemotron Nano 3 from Nvidia (30B total, 3B active) is off to a strong start, maybe the best of any Nemotron model to date.
4. OCR models like DeepSeek OCR and @allen_ai's OlmoCR 2 are overperforming. Quietly one of Ai2's most impactful releases yet.

Here's an abbreviated list of the top 10 models per size category (full list on the website):
- <1B - Mostly Qwen small models + SmolLM2, gemma-3-1b-it
- 1-5B - Qwen 1.5B/3B, Llama 3.2 1B/3B, Phi-3-mini, gemma-2-2b
- 7-9B - Llama 3.1/3/2 8B variants, Qwen 7B, Mistral 7B
- 10-50B - gpt-oss-20b, Qwen 14B/32B, DeepSeek-R1-Distill-32B, Mixtral 8x7B, Llama Vision 11B
- 50-100B - Llama 70B variants, Qwen3-Next-80B, Qwen 72B, DeepSeek-R1-Distill-70B
- 100-250B - gpt-oss-120b, Mixtral 8x22B, Mistral Large, Llama-4-Scout, Qwen3-235B, MiniMax-M2
- 250B+ - Llama 405B, DeepSeek R1/V3 variants, Kimi-K2, GLM-4.6

We use median instead of mean because outliers can skew averages dramatically. For example, the 1-5B bucket at 30d has a single outlier (Qwen2.5-1.5B-Instruct at 50.5M) that skews the mean from 0.57M to 5.51M ‚Äî nearly 10x. Using median + IQR (interquartile range, 25th-75th percentile) gives more representative reference values, which gives a simple metric to understand if a model is on track to be a top model in the ecosystem.

items.title: One of my favorite findings: Positional embeddings are just training wheels. They help convergence b...
items.content:
One of my favorite findings: Positional embeddings are just training wheels. They help convergence but hurt long-context generalization.

We found that if you simply delete them after pretraining and recalibrate for <1% of the original budget, you unlock massive context windows. Smarter, not harder.

AI will scr...
items.content:
We're feeding AI our best work for free, and nobody is talking about what happens next.

AI will scrape every blog and social media post you publish.
AI will scrape every single open-source code you share.
AI will scrape every tutorial you record.

And then, they will sell this info back to you in the form of tokens and soon, ads.

The economics of the future of content creation are broken.

If we don't fix this, we will regret it.

items.title: Every individual AI consultant I talk to (including myself) is massively changing their business app...
items.content:
Every individual AI consultant I talk to (including myself) is massively changing their business approach in 2026. 

2023 was about learning the new world. What is prompting. Should we ban this. What is a model. How do they work. Task force creation. Get a license for a few hundred employees then scale to an enterprise license. 

2024 was multimodal. Expanded feature usage. Efficiency with GPTs. Stored prompts. More image/vision. 

2025 was agents. Or at least early agents. It was figuring out how to make AI do stuff. Meaningful delegation. Reallocation of 0-20% of tasks. Bigger org structure shifts. Some AI enterprise license shifts as some players jumped ahead. 

2026 is multimodal agents and AI as a teammate. It‚Äôs burning down old workflows and process re-engineering. It‚Äôs moving away from retrofit tech and more toward net-new creation. It‚Äôs disposal and just-in-time software. 

This is a big year for competing re-inventing how work gets done. 

Growth mindset and systems thinking are the two biggest skills to curate.

items.title:
Two hours from now, you could have a problem solved AND a workout in. Here's the unlock:

For the sa...
items.content:
Two hours from now, you could have a problem solved AND a workout in. Here's the unlock:

For the same reason we all create and maintain https://t.co/6lkRloGo1l files, I need you to stop prompting Claude Code cold (say that 5 times fast). 

Instead, create context docs about who you are. 

Do it now.

Ex: create a paragraph, or a Google Doc, or collection of screenshots, or entire folder of info on who you are/what you stand for. This is Constitution context. Start small so it doesn't feel overwhelming. These are living documents. 

Then do the same for your Work: what do you do, what are your resources, what's working well, what isn't, what is the velocity of your business and/or career, what brings you energy, what depletes you, how do you define success, what does success look like, what would you change if you had a magic wand, what is a thing you desperately want but you're too ashamed to ask for it, etc.

Then do the same for your Personal Life or 2026 Goals.

Can't think of what to write? Have Claude interview you. NOT on the project at hand, but who YOU are.

I've been doing this the last two weekends. Just talking to Claude for hours and taking photos of my annual planning and KPIs or uploading culled down meeting transcripts.

Then, as needed, provide this context to Claude Code.

You can, in the next 2 hours, create an entire document with Claude on your 2026 goals, feed it to Claude Code, turn on all accepted edits during the session (shift+tab), tell it to work for an hour on something that will make you happy that will only require <10min at the end of investment time (ex: grabbing an API key, decisions about functionality), and go work out. 

In the next two hours, you could solve a problem AND get a work out in. 

And it'll be even better with insightful context docs.

Crazy easy prompt below to get you started ‚¨áÔ∏è

items.title:
Claude Code is killing the dashboard.

Every single tool is building integrations with Claude Code. ...
items.content:
Claude Code is killing the dashboard.

Every single tool is building integrations with Claude Code. No more context-switching to an external dashboard.

One of the latest examples I've seen:

@honeycombio's new MCP server lets you query observability data directly from your IDE, Claude Code, or Codex.

This is huge!

I always tell my customers they should get into observability, and as soon as they feel comfortable with what they have, they should double it.

Think about code in two groups:

1. Disposable code, which is the one you write for prototypes, experiments, and throwaway demos.

2. Durable code, which is the one you write and run in production.

But now, companies are deploying AI-assisted code to production at a rate we've never seen before.

This is the hard reality:

If you can't see what your code does, you can't improve it, debug it, or trust it.

I think observability is now more important than ever.

Having Honeycomb analyze all sorts of data points and deliver those insights right where you are writing code is huge:

‚Ä¢ When something breaks, you don't have to context-switch to a dashboard.

‚Ä¢ You can ask questions in natural language and get answers while you're still in the code.

We really don't need another dashboard.

Here is a great article about disposable and durable code: "Disposable Code Is Here to Stay, but Durable Code Is What Runs the World."

https://t.co/XWpTxNmHI2

Thanks to the Honeycomb team for collaborating with me on this post.

items.title: @OB1Kenoobi Oh, Tesla already has a world model and is trusted not to do anything whacky with consum...
items.content:
@OB1Kenoobi Oh, Tesla already has a world model and is trusted not to do anything whacky with consumer data. It already has a camera and microphones aimed at people in its cars. 

Getting a robot into the home and making it very useful means you gotta allow a world model with cameras and microphones into your home. 

You are right that trust is the biggest factor. 

My Neo arrives later this year and this will be a huge topic about robotics.

Look at @maticrobots which already has done that. All data stays inside the robot and doesn't go to the cloud. 

So we know it's possible to do a robot in a privacy-protecting way. Will be watching to see how @1x_tech approaches this topic when it releases later this year.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Detailed thread about home robots, world models, and privacy. Tesla has world model and camera/mic trust. Getting useful home robots requires allowing cameras/mics. Mentions maticrobots keeps all data local. Will watch how 1X Tech approaches privacy with NEO robot.
items.reasoning: Most substantive post in batch - comprehensive analysis of home robot privacy challenges, world model requirements, specific company examples (Tesla, Matic, 1X Tech), and trust as key factor. Valuable technical and market insight.
items.summary_html: Detailed thread about home robots, world models, and privacy. Tesla has world model and camera/mic trust. Getting useful home robots requires allowing cameras/mics. Mentions maticrobots keeps all data local. Will watch how 1X Tech approaches privacy with NEO robot.
items.content_html:
@OB1Kenoobi Oh, Tesla already has a world model and is trusted not to do anything whacky with consumer data. It already has a camera and microphones aimed at people in its cars.

Getting a robot into the home and making it very useful means you gotta allow a world model with cameras and microphones into your home.

You are right that trust is the biggest factor.

My Neo arrives later this year and this will be a huge topic about robotics.

Look at @maticrobots which already has done that. All data stays inside the robot and doesn't go to the cloud.

So we know it's possible to do a robot in a privacy-protecting way. Will be watching to see how @1x_tech approaches this topic when it releases later this year.

items.title: I've spent a better part of my morning trying to get my wife to get access to my Prime free shipping...
items.content:
I've spent a better part of my morning trying to get my wife to get access to my Prime free shipping to our home.

Her account was linked to mine for years, but was always having issues with shipping. 

In the end it took a call to Amazon customer service to resolve this issue. 

This should be the *rock bottom* technical problem that should be easy to resolve with just a few clicks (not even AI!), but here we are, still needing bespoke technical help from a human in the year 2026.

From everything I know about the "digital transformation" most of our technological stack is like this. 

Which is why I remain bearish on any significant impact that the AI will have in the immediate turn on the vast majority of real world economic use cases.

items.summary: Personal experience with Amazon account linking issues leads to skepticism about AI impact on real-world use cases due to poor underlying tech stack

items.title: Most machine learning systems that connect language to perception or action require large datasets o...
items.content:
Most machine learning systems that connect language to perception or action require large datasets of labeled examples collected offline before training begins.

This paper takes a different approach: an embodied agent with a robot arm learns the meanings of words like "red," "left of," and "store" through real-time conversation with a human instructor, asking clarifying questions when it encounters unknown terms.

The agent doesn't just memorize associations‚Äîit builds compositional representations, so learning "left of" from a few examples lets it understand "to the left of the pantry" in novel commands.

The system uses a cognitive architecture called Soar rather than neural networks, which means learning happens through symbolic rule formation rather than gradient updates, and the agent can explain why it made certain choices.

Read with an AI tutor: https://t.co/f8u8HF1Qtm

PDF: https://t.co/toC7bdVK81

items.summary: Burkov summarizes paper on embodied agents learning word meanings through real-time conversation using Soar cognitive architecture rather than neural networks
items.reasoning: Educational technical content about alternative approach to grounded language learning; good summary of academic work

items.title:
@theinformation There are several problems facing Rivian. 

First, getting the consumer to buy an el...
items.content:
@theinformation There are several problems facing Rivian. 

First, getting the consumer to buy an electric truck. This is why Ford failed and why Cybertruck is not doing all that well.  

2. Rivian doesn't have very good autonomy and won't for at least another year. Even then, I don't believe it will be anywhere close to what Tesla can offer.  

3. Rivian is just ramping up and don't have a brand that anybody in America really understands, likes, or sees. 

Teslas are everywhere in most cities, whereas Rivians are not. That makes people comfortable with the Tesla brand, but not with other brands.  Can Rivian change all this? I don't see how, but I'll be watching.

items.title: VLA models are systems that combine three capabilities into one framework: seeing the world through ...
items.content:
VLA models are systems that combine three capabilities into one framework: seeing the world through cameras, understanding natural language instructions like "pick up the red apple," and generating the actual motor commands to make a robot do it. 

Before these unified models existed, robots had separate modules for vision, language, and movement that were stitched together with manual engineering, which made them brittle and unable to handle new situations.

This review paper covers over 80 VLA models published in the past three years, organizing them into a taxonomy based on their architectures‚Äîsome use a single end-to-end network, others separate high-level planning from low-level control, some use diffusion models for smoother action sequences.

The paper walks through how these models are trained using both internet data and robot demonstration datasets, then maps out where they're being applied. The later sections lay out the concrete technical problems that remain unsolved.

Read online with an AI tutor: https://t.co/1UbyDI1ZQT

PDF: https://t.co/jvuh8x43ZD

items.summary: Burkov explains VLA (Vision-Language-Action) models that combine seeing, understanding instructions, and generating motor commands; reviews 80+ papers and their architectures

items.summary_html: At CES, Goertek showed Apple Vision Pro-like reference model weighing only 100 grams. Expects Apple to release much lighter Vision Pro that looks like glasses but superior to lightweight 'information snacking' glasses
items.content_html:
@Yuchenj_UW At CES @Goertek_USA was showing off something like an Apple Vision Pro reference model that only weighs 100 grams.

I expect that Apple will have a much lighter Apple Vision Pro, which will look like glasses, but be far superior to the lightweight ones that can only do information snacking.

So the next 24 months will be highly interesting in seeing where things are going.

items.title: So far, my most-used app in 2026, by far, is Apple's Notes app. I find myself writing quick ideas or...
items.content:
So far, my most-used app in 2026, by far, is Apple's Notes app. I find myself writing quick ideas or prompts in Notes and then sending those to Runway or Claude Code, depending on what I want to do.

It's really just about speed. Notes is the fastest way to get a sentence or two down. And now a sentence or two is often all you need to kick off something. Notes has accidentally become the starting point for most of what I make.
items.author: @c_valenzuelab
items.summary: Workflow insight: Apple Notes has become the starting point for AI workflows, with quick ideas sent to Runway or Claude Code

items.content_html:
So far, my most-used app in 2026, by far, is Apple's Notes app. I find myself writing quick ideas or prompts in Notes and then sending those to Runway or Claude Code, depending on what I want to do.

items.title:
The shift to autonomous enterprise starts with a mindset reset.

AI is no longer about task augmenta...
items.content:
The shift to autonomous enterprise starts with a mindset reset.

AI is no longer about task augmentation, it is about role transformation.

We are moving from:

‚Ä¢ People supported by tools
to
‚Ä¢ Personas augmented and partially offloaded to AI agents

This demands that organizations rethink strategy, structure, and culture together.
Not one at a time.

items.content:
@nymbusjp Actually it wasn't. 

I studied Automotive innovation all my career. 

Only Elon put the computer into every vehicle.

Everyone else had the same tech. Remember, I had a ride in the first Mercedes. 

They all gave up.

VW has its name on the Stanford building where Waymo started. 

In Silicon Valley we all knew who was leading.

And I recorded many of them in line in 2018 telling me so. 

It just takes time, that's all. 

So many argued with me that cars needed LiDARs to self drive. 

We now know so many just don't listen.

items.title:
AI has provided a more plausible solution to the Fermi Paradox, IMO.

Previously, scientists believe...
items.content:
AI has provided a more plausible solution to the Fermi Paradox, IMO.

Previously, scientists believed that civilizations fail to reach an interstellar level because they overheat the climate, destroy each other with nuclear weapons, or succumb to viruses.

It's more likely, though, that thanks to developing AI, these advanced civilizations simply become dumb.

items.content:
@nymbusjp I knew he would get there in 2018 and invested then. 

It was already way better than anything anyone else had.

But I had a front-row seat. Mercedes gave me its first ride in its first AI-driven car. Elon gave me the first ride in the first Tesla. And I had many other firsts. Including first video of a Waymo on YouTube. 

Glad to see you aboard.

Now you get to see how decisions Elon made a decade ago will matter to Robotaxis.

@KettlebellDan I have 61 lists focused mostly on the tech industry. They are the most complete tech industry lists here on X, particularly regarding the AI sector. For instance, I have 37,000 people and 7,700 companies on my AI lists.

I use them on my mobile phone so I can see what a specific community is talking about, but mostly I bring them into X-Pro on a web browser. My setup includes:

1. Eight different tabs
2. About ten different lists per tab

X-Pro lets me watch them in real time without being filtered. It's a little crazy, but it gives me the ability to watch the world go by.

I have lists of crypto, augmented and virtual reality, security, investors, founders, tech journalists, and a few others as well.

My lists: https://t.co/9eRY65x3IQ

items.title:
The companies leading this shift share one pattern.

They know how to adapt platforms, not individua...
items.content:
The companies leading this shift share one pattern.

They know how to adapt platforms, not individual tools.

The formula is simple: 3 plus 1

1. Define your narrative for the platform, this is the north star for transformation.
2. Measure what you do, and connect metrics directly to value streams.
3. Create a movement, including capability building and governance.
4. The '+1': Prioritize UI/UX, because change sticks only when people pull the technology instead of being pushed into it.
items.author: @Ronald_vanLoon

items.reasoning: Framework for AI platform adoption but low engagement; somewhat generic advice

items.title:
I've consulted for 100+ companies over the last 3 years.

You'd be shocked at how many teams struggl...
items.content:
I've consulted for 100+ companies over the last 3 years.

You'd be shocked at how many teams struggle to build and deploy AI/ML systems that work for real users.

Many of these teams are running workflows in spreadsheets and have no clue how to implement a process that scales and helps them build high-quality software.

Every time I meet one of these teams, I learn something new about what works and what doesn't when building AI/ML systems in the real world.

That's the foundation of my AI/ML Engineering program.

It's not a collection of theoretical concepts; it's a collection of lessons that I've learned the hard way:

1. The things I've seen failing
2. The things I've seen working
3. The patterns that separate production systems from weekend demos

The next cohort starts February 2, 2026.

I walk you through the entire process, from framing a problem correctly to deploying and monitoring a system that actually works.

You can join at https://t.co/iZifcK7UTF.

items.title: üçû People don't believe me my local artesanal bakery does not have a bread slicer and is not planning...
items.content:
üçû People don't believe me my local artesanal bakery does not have a bread slicer and is not planning on buying one ü•π

They also are always very quickly sold out of bread at about 11am (been like that for the last 4 years) and no they won't scale up to produce more loaves of bread eventhough demand is through the roof here

Why you say? Because it's not worth for my baker to produce more bread because the higher tax they'd have to pay would remove most of the increased profits they'd get

So why scale up?

Buying a bread slicer would make the product even more attractive and that is a probelm because it'd increase sales even more and they don't want that because then they'd be sold out by 9am!

It's a tale of classic Southern European economics

It's kinda fun to observe, like text book economics you studied in school played out in front of you with a product as basic as a loaf of bread that is hard to obtain

(Obviously I could go to the supermarket to buy bread there and they do have a slicer but we're hipsters and like the artesanal bakery more)
items.author: @levelsio
items.summary: Levelsio's long post about Portuguese bakery economics and tax disincentives for scaling
items.reasoning: Not AI/ML related - economics/lifestyle content.
